history.content:
Can't speak for 188 as I haven't taken it, but I can for 61C. Someone else feel free to edit below about 188.

Neither book was required for 61C this past semester, but I found them both to be worth the purchase. I went through the latter in the first 2-3 weeks to get a crash course on C programming and it was a great resource on C, since, well, it was written by the guys who created it. Others may have different opinions about the usefulness of it; I'm sure a motivated student would be fine with some free online C tutorial and doing exercises/experimenting with the language on their own. As for the other book, I found keeping up with the suggested readings was one of the main reasons I did well in the class, particularly in the middle third of it. It also has a lot of interesting historical and practical implementation notes that while not part of 61C, helped me better understand the motivation for a lot of concepts.

TL;DR: Highly recommend buying at least Computer Organization and Design and reading it; you can do without K&R's C Programming Language if you're familiar with C up to and including structs, pointers, and memory management, otherwise I think it's worth it for the structure of it and the exercises.

_______

For 188, the lecture notes where way more relevant to the content.

children.subject: I read both books for 61c and found them very helpful. The lectures weren't always enough for me. Some people probably skip the books and do ok, but I would recommend having them both available.

I found the textbooks for 61C to be verrry helpful. There is a lot of detail covered in the course, especially for the RISC-V portion, and I felt that the textbook filled in some gaps I was curious about. Regarding the textbook for C, I found this helpful too, but not nearly as much.

history.content: Is the Russell textbook ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE for 188 and the textbooks COMPUTER ORGANIZATION+DESIGN RISC-V ED. + C PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE (ANSI C) for 61C required? Which ones are worth getting even if not required?
history.subject: CS 61C & 188 Textbooks
